page.description: Open an existing set in its own session - the session will be closed when the set is closed.
page.syntax: <Set> as P = SET.Open_Session(C setname [,N file_open_mode|SQL::Arguments args [,C password]] )

argument.name: setname
argument.description: The name of a set. The extension ".set" is assumed.

argument.name: file_open_mode|SQL
argument.description: Optional. Determines the access privileges that apply to the open set file. You can use one of the following system variables:

argument.name: password
argument.description: Optional. Needed if the set has been encrypted, and the default encryption key has not been set (using the [DEFAULT_ENCRYPTION_KEY_SET()] function), of if the set was encrypted using a different encryption key than the default encryption key.

discussion.p: SET.OPEN_SESSION() opens a set in a new session and returns a pointer to the set. Returns the <Set> pointer to the set.
Contrast this with the [SET.OPEN()] method which opens the set in the current session, making the primary table of the set into the primary table of the session.
See [TABLE.OPEN()] for a description of the Open_Mode and Password parameters.

section.description: where alias is the alias of the table in the set.
section.note: If you want to open a set from a button or event on a form, you must use SET.OPEN_SESSION(), and not [SET.OPEN()].

section.title: Example
section.description: Assume this script is attached to a button on a form.
section.example: dim s as P dim t1 as P dim t2 as P s = set.open_session("invoice") t1 = s.invoice_header 'get a pointer to the customer table t2 = s.customer 'move to the last record in the invoice set t1.fetch_last() ui_msg_box("Note","Last order was placed by: " + t2.lastname 'close the set s.close()
